questions.text: This fundus appearance is seen in which form of refractive error?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myopia

 

Option A.

 

This fundus picture shows:

 

  • Mild tilting of disc
  • Characteristic temporal crescent
  • Grossly tessellated background

 

All these above-mentioned features are suggestive of Myopia.

 

Additional features:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypermetropia: Optic Disc: The optic nerve head may appear smaller or may have a crowded appearance due to the smaller eye size typically associated with hypermetropia. This can sometimes be mistaken for papilledema, which is swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure.

 

Option C. Astigmatism: There is no characteristic fundus findings in eyes with astigmatism.

 

Option D. Presbyopia: There are no characteristic findings in eyes with presbyopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tessellated fundus is most commonly seen in myopia, as the retinal thinning associated with this condition makes the choroidal vessels more apparent, giving the retina its characteristic mosaic-like appearance.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 35

questions.text: A child was referred from school screening camp due to difficulty in seeing blackboard. The teacher mentioned that he was squinting (half-shutting) his eyes while seeing the blackboard. What do you think is the probable cause for this?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myopia

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms of myopia include –

 

  • Defective distant vision hence it is also known as near-sightedness.
  • Asthenopia symptoms
  • Squinting (half-shutting) of eyes – this is done to achieve greater clarity of stenopaeic vision.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 33

questions.text: A 12-year-old female student complains of experiencing blurred vision and difficulty seeing objects in the distance. On examination, her eyes appeared normal with vision of 6/6 in both eyes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudo Myopia

 

Option B: A school-going girl experiencing difficulty in seeing distant objects while having a visual acuity of 6/6 suggests a diagnosis of Pseudo myopia. It has been caused most probably due to increase in near-work like reading, writing, or using digital devices leading to overstimulation of ciliary muscle.

 

MYOPIA TYPES

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Index myopia refers to myopia caused by changes in the refractive index of the lens or other ocular media, often related to metabolic changes, and would not usually resolve to show a normal vision of 6/6 during an eye examination.

 

Option C. Simple myopia, or true myopia, is a permanent change in the eye where the eyeball is too long relative to the focusing power of the cornea and lens. This would usually result in a permanent decrease in distance vision, not intermittent symptoms.

 

Option D. Induced myopia can be caused by various factors, including medications, increased blood sugar levels, or exposure to various environmental factors. Like index myopia, it would not typically present with normal vision during an examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis for a patient experiencing blurred distance vision intermittently but showing normal vision on examination is pseudo myopia, which is often due to a transient spasm of the ciliary muscles after prolonged close work.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of eye 22nd edition Page 71

questions.text: Most common form of Myopia is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Axial Myopia

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Index myopia - These results from changes in the refractive index of the eye's media, usually the lens, which can occur with conditions such as nuclear cataract or in cases of blood sugar fluctuations (as in diabetes).

 

Option B. Positional myopia - This is a less common term that might refer to myopia caused by the lens being positioned too close to the cornea, but it is not a widely recognized classification.

 

Option C. Curvatural myopia - This form of myopia occurs due to an increase in the curvature of the cornea or lens, which causes light rays to be over-converged and focus in front of the retina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Axial myopia is the most common form of myopia and is caused by the elongation of the axial length of the eye, leading to distant objects being focused in front of the retina and appearing blurred.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 33

questions.text: A Myopic patient was posted for Radial Keratotomy. What is the size of the optical zone left while making Peripheral Corneal Incisions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 mm

 

Explanation:

 

  • Radial Keratotomy is one of the Surgical Procedures done for correction of Myopia.
  • It is a type of Refractive Keratoplasty which is done to Modify the Refractive Power of the Cornea.
  • In this, Multiple Radial Incisions are made in the periphery of the cornea leaving a Central 4mm Optical Zone.
  • These incisions on Healing cause Flattening of the Corneal Curvature.

 

Education Objective:

 

Central Optional Zone in Radial Keratotomy is 4mm.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 592

questions.text: Functional Hypermetropia occurs in which of the nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oculomotor nerve

 

Option A:

 

  • Functional hypermetropia is the difficulty in reading or seeing nearby objects due to paralysis of accommodation.
  • Accommodation has 3 components:
    1. Constriction of pupil: via Sphincter pupillae
    2. Convergence: via Medial Recti
    3. Curvature increases of lens: via Ciliary muscle contraction
       
  • These 3 things are mediated via Oculomotor nerve.
  • Thus, Functional hypermetropia is seen in patients with third nerve palsy and internal ophthalmoplegia (paralysis of sphincter and dilator pupillae).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV): This nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, which primarily contributes to the rotation of the eye. Trochlear nerve palsy affects eye movement but does not directly impact accommodation or refractive status like hypermetropia.

 

Option C. Abducens Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): The abducens nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abduction. Palsy of this nerve leads to an inability to move the eye laterally, but it does not affect accommodation or cause hypermetropia.

 

Option D. Optic Nerve (Cranial Nerve II): The optic nerve transmits visual information from the retina to the brain. Palsy or damage to the optic nerve affects vision, but it does not cause hypermetropia as it is not involved in the accommodation process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional hypermetropia can occur as a result of oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III) palsy, which impairs the ciliary muscle's ability to accommodate, leading to difficulty focusing on near objects.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 29

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with complaints of defective vision in the right eye associated with erythropsia and cyanopsia. On examination it was seen that his pupil was jet black and the Purkinje image test revealed only two images. What is likely to be the conclusion after performing retinoscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High Hypermetropia

 

Option C:

 

  • The clinical signs – a jet black pupil, and presence of only two Purkinje images - point towards aphakia.
  • Total power of the eye is reduced from +60D to about +44D – hence eye becomes highly hypermetropic.
  • On performing retinoscopy on a hypermetropic/emmetropic/ myopic eye with power <1D: the red reflex is along movement.
  • To correct high hypermetropia, high power plus lenses are used.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Low Hypermetropia: Hypermetropia (farsightedness) occurs when the eye is too short or the lens is too weak, causing light to focus behind the retina. However, the absence of the lens in aphakia leads to a much more significant refractive error than what would be classified as "low" hypermetropia.

 

Option B. Low Myopia: Myopia (near-sightedness) is when the eye is too long or the lens is too strong, causing light to focus in front of the retina. Aphakia does not typically result in myopia, as the removal of the lens significantly reduces the eye's refractive power.

 

Option D. High Myopia: As mentioned, aphakia generally does not lead to myopia. The condition results in a loss of refractive power, not an excess of it, which would be necessary to cause high myopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In aphakic patients, where the natural lens of the eye is absent, retinoscopy typically reveals high hypermetropia due to the significant reduction in the eye's refractive power.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 31

questions.text: An IT personnel in their mid-40s diagnosed with hypermetropia and presbyopia needs a new set of spectacles. What type of glasses can be prescribed to this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Progressive

 

Option D:

 

  • Progressive addition lenses have no distracting lines between the different prescription areas.
  • They give clear vision at all distances—from distance vision at the top of the lens, through intermediate vision for closer objects, to near vision at the bottom of the lens.
  • They are particularly useful for computer work, and are available in high index, plastic, glass and polycarbonate material.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Unifocal: Unifocal lenses have only one prescription throughout the entire lens. They can be optimized for either distance or near vision, but not both. This would not be suitable for someone who needs correction for both hypermetropia and presbyopia.

 

Option B. Bifocal with ARC: Bifocal lenses have two distinct optical powers – one for distance and one for near vision, typically with a visible line separating them. ARC stands for Anti-Reflective Coating, which reduces glare and is beneficial for computer work. Bifocals could be a viable option, providing both near and far corrections.

 

Option C. Flat Top Trifocal: Trifocal lenses provide three ranges of vision: near, intermediate (like computer screens), and distance. A flat-top trifocal has a segment at the top for distance, a middle segment for intermediate vision, and a lower segment for near vision. This could be a good choice for an IT professional who requires clear vision at multiple distances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a person in their mid-40s with hypermetropia and presbyopia, especially someone working in IT, progressive lenses or flat top trifocals are recommended to accommodate near, intermediate, and distance vision requirements seamlessly.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 81

questions.text: Identify the type of lens in this picture:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rigid Gas Permeable Lens

 

Option B:

 

  • Oxygen-permeable or rigid gas-permeable lenses are made of a firm, durable plastic that transmits oxygen.
  • Materials used include copolymer of PMMA and silicone and cellulose acetate butyrate.
  • As they do not contain water, they resist deposits and are less likely than soft contact lenses to harbor bacteria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Soft Contact Lens: Made of soft, flexible plastics that allow oxygen to pass through to the cornea, soft contact lenses are comfortable and easier to adapt to than rigid lenses.

 

Option C. Hard Contact Lens: Made of a rigid, durable plastic, hard contact lenses are less comfortable and less oxygen-permeable compared to soft or rigid gas permeable lenses and are rarely used today.

 

Option D. Scleral Contact Lens: Large-diameter lenses that vault over the entire corneal surface and rest on the sclera, scleral lenses are used for specific corneal irregularities and provide comfort for sensitive eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigid Gas Permeable Lens: are more durable than soft contact lenses, provide clearer vision, and are breathable, allowing more oxygen to reach the cornea.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 82

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with aphakia in the right eye presents for vision correction. The ophthalmologist prescribes spectacles to address the refractive error. During the examination, a specific type of visual distortion or aberration is observed in the right eye. What is the likely aberration noted?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pin Cushion

 

Option B:

 

  • Spectacle correction in aphakia causes spherical aberration in the form of pincushion effect.
  • Image appears pinched in the center.
  • Image distortion increases progressively in both directions.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Barrel Distortion: This occurs when the magnification of the image decreases with increasing distance from the optical axis. In optics, it is seen with high minus lenses.

 

Option C. Coma: This aberration occurs when an optical system images an off-axis point source, resulting in an asymmetric, comet-like blur. In the human eye, coma can be caused by imperfections in the lens or corneal surface, often exacerbated under conditions of large pupil diameters.

 

Option D. Oblique Astigmatism: This type of astigmatism happens when light rays entering the eye off the optical axis have different refractive errors in different meridians. It's not specific to aphakia but is a common issue in spectacle and contact lens corrections, especially when the gaze is directed significantly away from the optical center of the lens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an aphakic patient corrected with spectacles, "Pin Cushion Distortion" is the typical visual aberration observed, where the strong positive lenses cause straight lines to appear curved inwards due to increased magnification away from the lens's optical axis.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 77

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of blurred vision in both eyes. She has a history of cataract surgery in both eyes, resulting in aphakia. She desires improved visual acuity and seeks the most appropriate intervention for her condition. Which one out these would be the best choice for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IOL Placement

 

Option A. IOL Placement (Intraocular Lens): This is typically the best choice for correcting vision after cataract surgery. An IOL is a synthetic lens implanted inside the eye that replaces the eye's natural lens. It offers permanent correction and does not require the maintenance that comes with contact lenses, or the visual distortions often associated with spectacles in aphakic patients.

 

  • The best optical correction for aphakia is the implantation of an intraocular lens (IOL) at the time of lens extraction or cataract surgery as a primary procedure and secondary IOL implantation.

 

ADVANTAGES OF IOL OVER SPECTACLES IN APHAKIA:

 

  • Minimal after-care of patient
  • Minimum aniseikonia
  • Rapid return of binocularity
  • Normal peripheral vision.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Contact Lens: Contact lenses can provide good visual acuity in aphakic patients, offering a more natural field of vision than spectacles. However, they require daily maintenance and may not be suitable for all patients, especially the elderly, due to handling and hygiene challenges.

 

Option C. Spectacles: While spectacles are a non-invasive option, they can create significant visual distortions (like barrel or pin cushion distortion) in aphakic patients. They also offer a limited field of vision and can be cumbersome due to the thick lenses required for aphakic correction.

 

Option D. Arcuate Keratotomy: This surgical procedure is used to correct astigmatism, not aphakia. It involves making arc-shaped incisions in the cornea to change its shape and correct refractive errors. It's not suitable for aphakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with aphakia following cataract surgery, the placement of an intraocular lens (IOL) is the best choice for long-term, maintenance-free visual acuity improvement.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 77

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinoscope

 

Option A:

 

  • Retinoscopy or Skiascopy or the shadow test is the most practical method of estimating the condition of the refraction objectively.
  • Works on the principle of neutralization.
  • Types – spot and streak retinoscope.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Direct Ophthalmoscope  

 

 

Option C. Perkin’s tonometer

 

 

Option D. Focimeter

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The instrument shown is a streal retinoscope.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 59

questions.text: A patient who is scheduled for cataract surgery needs to have the curvature of the anterior surface of the cornea tested in order to calculate the intraocular lens (IOL) power. Which of the following instruments should the optometrist choose for the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ophthalmometer

 

Option D:

 

  • A Keratometer (Ophthalmometer) measures the curvature of the anterior surface of the cornea at two points about 1.25 mm on either side of its center.
  • Double refracting prisms are present.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Refractometer: Estimates refractive error of the eye.

 

Option B. Priestley- Smith Retinoscope: Estimates refractive error of the eye.

 

 

Option D. Specular Microscope: Measures corneal endothelial cell count and morphology.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ophthalmometer is the instrument used for measuring the curvature of the cornea.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 65

questions.text: What is the refractive state of the newborn eye?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypermetropia

 

Option C:

 

  • The eye of the newborn is hypermetropic.
  • The infant eye undergoes rapid growth in the first few years of life to reach an axial of length of about 23 mm by the age of 3 years.
  • From 3 to 14 years of age, the axial length increases further by 1 mm and the power of the crystalline lens changes to achieve and maintain emmetropia.
  • This entire process from birth onwards is known as emmetropization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Emmetropia, is a state where the eye has perfect refractive power, meaning there is no need for corrective lenses. Light rays coming into the eye are focused precisely on the retina, providing clear vision. However, this is not common in newborns, as their eyes are still developing.

 

Option B. In Myopia (Short-sightedness), the eye's refractive power is too strong, or the eyeball is elongated. This causes light rays to focus in front of the retina, making distant objects appear blurred. Newborns are rarely myopic; this condition usually develops in childhood or adolescence.

 

Option D. Anisometropia, is a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive power between the two eyes. It is not a common refractive state at birth but can develop as the child grows. Anisometropia can lead to amblyopia if not corrected, as the brain tends to favor the eye with better focus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the typical refractive state of the newborn eye is hypermetropia, where the eye's refractive power is too weak, leading to light focusing behind the retina. This condition is common and usually self-corrects as the child grows.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 70

choices.text: Absence of Lens in Pupillary Area
Backward Displacement of the Lens

questions.text:
A patient presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of blurry near vision, eye strain, and headaches while performing close-up tasks such as reading. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist determines that the patient has refractive error. While counselling the patient regarding his refractive status, the ophthalmologist draws the following ray diagram.

 

 

All of the following ocular changes can cause this condition, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steeper Cornea

 

Option C:

 

ETIOLOGICAL CLASSIFICATION OF HYPERMETROPIA

 

  • Axial Hypermetropia – Decrease in Axial Length
  • Curvatural Hypermetropia – Flatter Curvature of Cornea
  • Index Hypermetropia – Decrease to Refractive Index with Old Age
  • Positional Hypermetropia – Posterior Displacement of Lens
  • Absence of Crystalline Lens

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Shorter Axial Length: This is a primary cause of hypermetropia. When the axial length of the eye (the distance from the front to the back) is shorter than normal, it causes light rays to focus behind the retina, leading to hypermetropia.

 

Option B. Absence of Lens in Pupillary Area (Aphakia): The absence of the lens typically results in hypermetropia. The lens plays a crucial role in focusing light onto the retina. Without it, the eye loses some of its refractive power, causing light to be focused behind the retina.

 

Option D. Backward Displacement of the Lens: If the lens is displaced backward, it can lead to hypermetropia. This displacement increases the focal length within the eye, causing light to focus behind the retina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A steeper cornea actually causes myopia, not hypermetropia. In myopia, the cornea bends light too much, or the eye is too long, causing light rays to focus in front of the retina. Therefore, a steeper cornea would not cause hypermetropia, but the opposite.

 

Ref: Comprehensive ophthalmology Khurana page 29

questions.text: Pseudo Papillitis is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypermetropia

 

Option B:

 

  • In case of hypermetropia, the fundus may appear normal on ophthalmoscopy.
  • A bright reflex, suggesting the appearance of watered silk, is commoner in hypermetropic than in emmetropic or myopic eyes
  • In hyperopia, the optic disc appears small with crowding of vessels and nerve fibers. The resultant hyperaemic appearance of the disc mimics papillitis, hence called pseudo papillitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Myopia (Short-sightedness): In myopia, the eye is longer than normal, which can affect the appearance of the optic nerve head. However, myopia is more commonly associated with other changes in the eye, such as posterior staphyloma, and does not typically present as pseudo papillitis.

 

Option C. Aphakia (Absence of the lens): Aphakia, the absence of the lens, either congenital or usually due to surgical removal, changes the eye's refractive state. However, it does not inherently cause changes in the optic disc appearance that would be mistaken for papilledema.

 

Option D. Pseudophakia (Artificial lens implant): Pseudophakia refers to the condition of having an artificial lens implant, typically after cataract extraction. While this alters the eye's focusing ability, it does not typically result in changes to the optic disc that mimics papilledema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that pseudo papillitis, a condition where the optic disc appears swollen similar to papilledema but is non-pathological, is typically associated hypermetropia.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 76

choices.text: Regular Astigmatism with the Rule
Regular Astigmatism Against the Rule

questions.text: In a patient tested for refractive error, the greater and least curvature was at right angles to each other, and the vertical meridian was more curved. Identify the type of error:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Regular Astigmatism with the Rule

 

Option A: The vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal meridian. This is the most common form of regular astigmatism.

 

Regular Astigmatism: This occurs when the principal meridians are perpendicular to each other. It can be further classified as: With the rule astigmatism and against the rule astigmatism.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Irregular Astigmatism: This occurs when the principal meridians are not perpendicular to each other. This can be due to an eye injury, surgery, or keratoconus.

 

Option C. Oblique Astigmatism: This is a type of regular astigmatism where the steepest curve lies in between the 120-degree and 150-degree meridians or between the 30-degree and 60-degree meridians, neither vertical nor horizontal.

 

Option D. Against-the-Rule Astigmatism: The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greater curvature in the vertical meridian and the meridians being at right angles to each other – the correct type of refractive error is A. Regular Astigmatism with the rule.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 52

questions.text: In this Sturm’s conoid, if the retina cuts the conoid at A, the condition is termed as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Compound Hypermetropic Astigmatism

 

Option B:

 

Both principal meridians of the eye are hypermetropic, but to different degrees, resulting in light focusing behind the retina in both meridians.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Simple Hypermetropic Astigmatism: One principal meridian of the eye is hypermetropic (farsighted), and the other is emmetropic (normal), causing light to focus behind the retina in one meridian only.

 

Option C. Simple Myopic Astigmatism: One principal meridian of the eye is myopic (nearsighted), and the other is emmetropic, causing light to focus in front of the retina in one meridian only.

 

Option D. Compound Myopic Astigmatism: Both principal meridians of the eye are myopic, but to different degrees, leading to light focusing in front of the retina in both meridians.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In compound hyperopic astigmatism, both the principal meridians of the eye are hypermetropic, but to different degrees, resulting in light focusing behind the retina in both meridians.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 53

questions.text: All are advantages of contact lens over spectacles except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Better magnification of image

 

Option B:

 

ADVANTAGES OF CONTACT LENS:

 

  • Less magnification of image
  • Elimination of aberration
  • Wider and better field of vision
  • Better suited for uniocular aphakia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Better Field of Vision: True. Contact lenses conform to the curvature of the eye, providing a wider field of vision and causing fewer vision distortions compared to spectacles.

 

Option C. Elimination of Aberration: True. Spectacles can sometimes introduce optical aberrations, especially towards the edges of the lenses. Contact lenses, being directly on the eye, largely eliminate these aberrations, providing clearer and more consistent vision.

 

Option D. Absence of Prismatic Effect: True. The prismatic effect is an issue with spectacles, particularly for those with strong prescriptions or when looking through the edge of the lenses. Contact lenses, fitting directly over the cornea, do not create this effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contact lenses offer several advantages over spectacles, including a better field of vision, elimination of aberration, and absence of prismatic effects. However, they do not provide better magnification of images, which is a function more related to the design of spectacle lenses.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 32

questions.text: An elderly woman came to the OPD with complaints of gradually progressive diminution of vision in right eye, not accompanied with pain. After examination she was diagnosed with mature senile cataract in right eye and underwent surgery for the same wherein her cataractous lens was removed. Now, which of the following UV rays can reach the retina in the operated eye?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) UV A

 

Explanation:

 

  • In aphakic patients, wavelengths in the UV-A region can reach the retina.
  • Intraocular lens implants, made up of polymethylmethacrylate, absorb only UV rays < 320 nm.
  • Modern intraocular lenses including polymethylmethacrylate, silicone and foldable acrylic are impregnated with UV-A absorbing substances called chromophores.
  • Polymethylmethacrylate lenses with UV filtering chromophores absorb wavelengths < 400 nm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an eye operated for cataract surgery, UV A rays can reach the retina.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of eye 22nd edition page 40

questions.text: The optical state of the patient being tested is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypermetropia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Myopia: In myopia the rays of light focus in front of the retina.

 

 

Option C. Emmetropia: In emmetropia the rays of light come to focus on the fovea.

 

 

 

Option D. Anisometropia: In anisometropia, the two eyes have different refraction errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypermetropia, the rays of light come to focus behind the retina.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of eye 22nd edition page 51

choices.text: Handle of instrument in alignment with axis of the cylindrical lens
Handle of instrument perpendicular to axis of the cylindrical lens
Axis of the cylinder in the instrument aligned with axis of the trial cylindrical lens
Axis of the cylinder in the instrument perpendicular to axis of the trial cylindrical lens

questions.text: In a 30-year-old patient with astigmatism, you are asked to confirm the axis of the cylinder. How will you orient the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Handle of instrument in alignment with the axis of the cylindrical lens

 

Option A:

 

  • The instrument shown in the picture is Jackson’s cross cylinder.
  • This is used to verify the axis and for confirmation of cylindrical power.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Handle of Instrument in Alignment with Axis of the Cylindrical Lens: This is not the correct method. Aligning the handle of the Jackson cross cylinder with the axis of the patient's cylindrical lens would not effectively test the axis.

 

Option B. Handle of Instrument Perpendicular to Axis of the Cylindrical Lens: This method is also incorrect. The handle orientation does not directly determine the axis testing with the Jackson cross cylinder.

 

Option D. Axis of the Cylinder in the Instrument Perpendicular to Axis of the Trial Cylindrical Lens: This orientation would not be correct for initially confirming the axis of the cylindrical lens. It is used after aligning the axes to refine the cylindrical power.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When confirming the axis of a cylindrical lens in astigmatism using a Jackson cross cylinder, align the axis of the cylinder within the instrument with the axis of the patient's current cylindrical correction. This alignment is crucial for accurate axis determination and refinement.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of eye 22nd edition page 67

questions.text: What is the type of lens used in this instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Convex Cylindrical Lens

 

Explanation:

 

  • The lens shown in the picture is Maddox Rod.
  • It is used in the diagnosis of extra-ocular muscle imbalance.
  • It consists of a series of powerful convex cylindrical lenses mounted side by side in a trial lens.
  • The row of cylinders forms a row of foci on the retina.
  • These foci join up and are seen as a line of light which lies at 90° to the axis of the Maddox rod.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maddox rod is made by placing a series of convex cylinders so that when a point source of light is seen through it, it appears as a line.

 

Ref: Clinical optics by Elkington Page: 67

questions.text: Prisms are used in all the following instruments except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keratometer

 

Option B:

 

  • Prisms are commonly used in ophthalmic instruments as reflectors of light.
  • The prism is designed and orientated so that total internal reflection occurs within it.
  • Instruments in which prisms are used include the slit lamp microscope, the applanation tonometer and the Indirect Ophthalmoscope.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Applanation Tonometer: This instrument is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP) and typically use prisms. It employs a flat-tipped probe to flatten (applanate) a small area of the cornea, and the force required for this applanation is used to estimate the IOP.

 

Option C. Indirect Ophthalmoscope: An indirect ophthalmoscope is used for examining the retina. It often incorporates prisms to adjust the path of light for proper visualization of the interior of the eye.

 

Option D. Slit Lamp Biomicroscope: A slit lamp is used to examine the various parts of the eye under high magnification. It typically includes prisms to direct light into the eye and to provide stereoscopic views of eye structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prisms are not used in keratometers.

 

Ref: Clinical optics by Elkington Page: 52

questions.text: A value of 0.75D was deduced from the retinoscopy reading as a part of drug correction. The likely drug used was?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyclopentolate

 

Explanation:

 

Rough estimate of refractive error after Retinoscopy is given by:

 

Amount of refractive error = Retinoscopic findings- deduction for distance- tonus allowance for cycloplegic drug used.

 

TONUS ALLOWANCE OF CYCLOPLEGIC DRUGS

 

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION PAGE 582

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a Mydriatic but not a Cycloplegic?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phenylephrine

 

Option D: Mydriasis refers to dilatation of pupil. It can be carried out by 2 mechanisms:

 

  • Active mydriasis: Sympathomimetic (Phenylephrine)
  • Passive mydriasis: Anticholiergic (Atropine)

 

Cycloplegia refers to absence of accommodation due to paralysis of ciliary muscle. It is carried out by anticholinergic drugs that block muscarinic receptor-mediated contraction of ciliary muscle.

 

  • Phenylephrine 5–10%, a selective alpha-1 agonist acts on dilator pupillae only. It does not act on ciliary muscle hence does not cause cycloplegia. Always to be used in combination with cycloplegics pre-op.
  • Used prior to fundus examination or retinal laser procedures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cyclopentolate: This is both a mydriatic and a cycloplegic agent. It dilates the pupil and also temporarily paralyzes the ciliary muscle, leading to loss of accommodation.

 

Option B. Homatropine: Like cyclopentolate, homatropine is also both a mydriatic and a cycloplegic. It dilates the pupil and affects accommodation.

 

Option C. Atropine: This is another example of a drug that is both a mydriatic and a cycloplegic. It causes prolonged pupil dilation and paralysis of accommodation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenylephrine is a mydriatic agent used to dilate the pupil without causing significant cycloplegia, making it suitable for procedures where pupil dilation is needed without affecting the eye's focusing ability.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF THE EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 155

questions.text: Homatropine was used for retinoscopic refraction. When is the ideal time for a post-mydriatic test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 Days Later

 

Option B: POST MYDRIATIC TEST

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Next Day: Patients in whom Tropicamide eye drop has been used as a cycloplegic agent can be called for post-mydriatic test the next day.

 

Option C. 1 Week Later: When atropine is used as a cycloplegic agent, PMT can be done after 10 days.

 

Option D. 2 Weeks Later: When atropine is used as a cycloplegic agent, PMT can be done after 10 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When homatropine is used for retinoscopic refraction, post-mydriatic test can be done after 3 days.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH ED PAGE 582
